Articles.Content:
Can anyone please explain the ksp dragsystem to me?

Because i want to land on eve(i know the atmosphere is thick, but: ) with a very heavy lander, i wanted to calculate the number of parachutes.... But i dont know what to do with this drag value....

I tried to calculate it with the assumption that this dragvalue equals drag coefficient times area, but it obviously does not....

Does anyone have an idea?

greetings

stoani

Edited September 7, 2013 by stoani96

Here is the drag equation for KSP:F_D = 0.5*rho*V^2*C_D*mF_D = force of dragrho = atmospheric densityV = velocityC_D = drag coefficientm = mass wtf is wrong with the forums now?

Edited September 7, 2013 by Kosmo-not

Drag on a part is 0.5 Cd A rho v^2

Cd is 0.008

A is the drag value times the mass.

Rho is the density (not the pressure, though they're related)

v is your air speed (surface speed, not orbit speed)

Add it up for all the parts in your vessel.

first of all: thank you!

but:

wtf is m in this equiation?

cause either the force has the wrong unit or c_d has one(m^2/kg), or am i wrong?

Go to KSP Wiki, type in Drag in the search box, press enter = Result.

Alternatively just use Parachute Calculator.
every part? even that ones, that are blocked by others?
Every part; this is a simplification that squad will some day fix, but they've been busy with more important tasks. You can use the FAR plugin to get more realistic aerodynamics.
Wtf do I have to do to get multiple lines of text in my posts these days? And where did the advanced text editor thing go?
Future reference, if you have technical questions (like geosynchronous orbit for kerbin(but I know you're smarter than that) first visit the wiki, it has loads of numbers and useful information.
